Literature Review: Rhythms and clocks in marine organisms are ubiquitous and play a crucial role in regulating the physiology and behavior of individuals, as well as their interactions with each other and with the environment. The study of these rhythms has expanded beyond the traditional circadian rhythms, which are the daily cycles that govern the sleep-wake cycle of animals, to include longer-term cycles such as circatidal, circalunar, and circannual rhythms. These rhythms are essential for the survival and adaptation of marine organisms in various ecological niches, including coral reefs, estuaries, and the open ocean.The concept of endogenous oscillators, which are internal biological clocks that regulate the rhythmic processes in organisms, has been extensively studied in marine animals. For example, the blue crab (Callinectes sapidus) has been found to have an endogenous circadian rhythm that regulates its feeding behavior, while the sea cucumber (Holothuria leucospilota) has an endogenous circatidal rhythm that controls its feeding and reproduction (1). Similarly, the coral (Anthozoa) has an endogenous circalunar rhythm that regulates its reproduction and larval settlement (2).In addition to endogenous oscillators, marine organisms also respond to environmental cycles, such as the tidal cycle, the lunar cycle, and the seasonal cycle. For example, the mussel (Mytilus galloprovincialis) has been found to have a circatidal rhythm that is synchronized with the tidal cycle, while the sea urchin (Strongylocentrotus purpuratus) has a circalunar rhythm that is synchronized with the lunar cycle (3, 4). The seasonal cycle also plays a crucial role in regulating the physiology and behavior of marine organisms, such as the migration of fish (5) and the spawning of corals (6).The study of rhythmicity in marine organisms has important implications for understanding how species will respond to environmental perturbations, including climate change. For example, changes in the tidal cycle and the lunar cycle can have significant impacts on the physiology and behavior of marine organisms, such as the disruption of feeding behavior and the alteration of reproduction (7, 8). Similarly, changes in the seasonal cycle can have significant impacts on the migration patterns and spawning behavior of marine organisms (9, 10).Furthermore, the study of rhythmicity in marine organisms has also led to the development of laboratory model systems that are used to disentangle key mechanistic principles. For example, the use of genetically modified zebrafish (Danio rerio) has allowed researchers to study the molecular mechanisms of circadian rhythms and circatidal rhythms (11, 12). Similarly, the use of microalgae (Chlamydomonas reinhardtii) has allowed researchers to study the molecular mechanisms of circadian rhythms and circalunar rhythms (13, 14).In conclusion, the study of rhythmicity in marine organisms is a rapidly evolving field that has important implications for understanding how species will respond to environmental perturbations, including climate change. The study of endogenous oscillators, environmental cycles, and the interconnection between these rhythms is essential for making better predictions of how species will respond to environmental changes.
